Not having watched this video as yet,  I have issues with these lamps as a chemist for a few reasons.  One,  the salt is held together by ionic bonds...  you need temperatures much hotter than a lamp to ionize the salt crystals.  Secondly,  a chemical "salt" consists of both positive and negative ions...  any temperatures high enough to break apart the saly into component ions will generate both types,  which will recombine as very tiny salt crystals the moment the heat is removed and the positive and negative charges are drawn back together.

What makes us feel good in one environment and not so good in another is both highly subjective and, at this point, absolutely not understood by science. Current science has no way to explain how feng shui works - simply changing the geometry of items in a given space will change how we feel in that space. The shape of the room itself changes how we feel in that room - a pyramid shaped room has different characteristics than a square room (hence the building of pyramids by ancient civilization). Crystals, including salt, do have a tremendous impact on a space, but the effect is much more subtle than "negative ions". As we gain a more sophisticated understanding of what life is and what consciousness is, we will begin to appreciate some of the tremendous qualities of crystals - qualities which are subtle in their effects and difficult for science to quantify. Still, while we can acknowledge that something is difficult to quantify, this does not imply that subtle qualities are merely imagined or somehow not real.

Ozone is a triple Oxygen molecule and breaks down rather quickly in an uncharged environment, like ground level. That's what makes it a good Oder eliminator, it oxidizes scents among other things. But you breath O2 not O3 so you only use it to sanitize the fabrics in a room.
Ozone is also produced by the Sun hitting our upper atmosphere. The solar wind keeps the ozone layer above us. Remove the Sun for any length of time and the ozone will break down into O2 which is more stable. That's why there is a hole in the Ozone at the poles No Sun for an extended time.
BTW, if you put a ham sandwich in an airtight container and them flooded it with ozone and walked away, the Ozone would break down pretty fast. No, don't ban ham sandwiches, Ozone WANTS to break down to O2 in an uncharged environment. It's not pollutants destroying the ozone layer. It's just the natural uncharged state of the Oxygen, that and O2 is also a hungry atom leading to Oxidation.

I think they're using an APCI-MS detector. This stands for atmospheric pressure chemical ionisation - mass spectrometer. I'm not sure whether this is the right way to test this hypothesis

A GC/Mass Spec requires an injection of the sample and a column of inert material to which the atomized sample travels.  The curvature of the mass spec section allows for heavier elements to fall out of "solution" which creates a resultant elemental analysis of the sample.  In no way is this piece of analytical equipment going to see ions of a sample.  The ion concentration in the air is measured with ionometer. These measurement devices usually contain an external tube electrode in which an additional, smaller tube electrode is insulated and a fan. DC voltage is applied to both electrodes and hence an electrical DC field is generated between both tube electrodes.

Serotonin is the hormone the mind outputs after doing something that is good for you. It's the reward stimulus. I do something that I like, my mind releases serotonin to let me know that I just did a good thing and thus should keep doing it. It's the "feel good" hormone because it makes you feel good.

Dopamine, on the other hand, is the hormone that makes you desire something. It does so to lead you to produce serotonin. I like cake since it makes me feel good, so my mind produces dopamine to make me crave cake.

Serotonin and dopamine's relationship can be shown as thus: I eat cake -> I produce serotonin, which reminds me that eating cake is good -> since my body knows that eating cake is good, it wants to make me eat more cake -> so it produces dopamine to make me desire cake -> and the cycle repeats. It's a cycle of desire and reward.

Do something too many times, and your mind gets used to it, strengthening the production of dopamine, and weakening the output of serotonin. This is the basis for addiction, btw.

This really boils down to the placebo effect, which is the paradoxical case of yes it both "works" and doesnt "work". A salt lamp might make someone feel better because they expect to feel better for even having the lamp turned on. Which is of course what the owner of the lamp wants in the end anyway. Throwing the scientific or rather often pseudo-scientific explanation only serves as a means to better convince the layman buyer that the product could plausibly work for their needs. Just another "ignorance is bliss," argument.

Said it before; I'll say it again... There is NOTHING in any such lamp that creates ions, positive or negative.
The ONLY thing it can do is trap some dust or particles out of the air.
How? The SALT attracts WATER from the air, forming a very thin film on the salt.
The LAMP heats the salt, creating a mild chimney effect, or convection current, that makes the air above it rise, 'pulling air' towards the lamp.
Any particles IN that air that reach the lamp STICK to the WATER film, thus "purifying" the air in that small area.
Period.
No Ions.
If air that's, considering the volume of air in any average sized room, "purified" to that microscopic degree, is 'good for you,' fine. But probably so far to the right of the decimal point in percentage as to be immeasurable.

Oh, and the directions that come with the lamps often say, 'wipe it off with a damp towel'... to remove the accumulated dust and start a new H2O film on the surface.

Himalayan BS, but a fine money-maker.

My main question, which unfortunately isn't addressed in this video:
Since charge is conserved, any process that produces and releases negative ions must produce an equal amount of positive charge. Where does it go? If it's also released into the air, if the ions don't immediately react with each other, like discussed in the video, then at least we'd breath in an equal amount of beneficial negative ions and detrimental positive ions, and their effect should cancel out.
With waterfalls and thunderstorms I can think of processes that transport away the positive charge (but then at some other location, wouldn't we have a drain for our negative ions?). How would that work with a salt or tourmaline lamp, or an air purifier? Wouldn't the air purifier become more and more positively charged and thus suck all the negative ions out of the air?
I guess the answer is somehow "ground", but I'd like to know more details.

Just as a little qualifier for the "such small numbers of ions are insignificant compared to how many gas molecules are in the air" - yes, but small numbers of molecules do literally everything cells do.
Signalling receptors are present in cells at numbers below 1000 molecules per cell for example.
A single molecule of ricin is enough to kill a cell.
Every time you breathe, you inhale on average half a litre of air - 500 cubic centimetres, which means indoors about 50 thousand ions according to the numbers we just saw.
I completely agree that it makes no sense for these to actually do anything to your cells because... they're NOT ricin, or peptides your cells understand as a signal for something, or other biologically active molecules. They're presumably random ions, and presumably mostly OH- or such mostly inert species. But purely a vanishingly small amount of molecules is not an argument at the cellular scale.

I was wrong I found out that it uses a compound called Magnesium Sulfate heptohydrate or smth like that. Under heat it releases water, that gets evaporated by heat of smth like 90C° and turns into tetrahydrate, during day it slowly absorbs moisture and chemicly bonds with it like some sort of a chemical sponge becoming heptahydrate again and cycle continues. Thing is that in the middle it very slowly turnes into monohydrate and is incapable of releasing water anymore so within like 100-300 cycles the lamp gets completely useless so i kinda was wrong with whole 500 cycles thing

Hi. So you've debunked the myth of the salt lamp. But there is another popular belief about salt's benefits for temporary relief from allergic asthma. Khewra, in Pakistan, the source of the pink Himalayan salt, has the world's 2nd largest salt mines. There they have a "hospital" of sorts where they treat people with seasonal asthma. The convention goes that the patient has to spend 110 hours inside the salt mines during the allergy season. This usually helps them through that season. I have observed this effect when my sister actually went through the treatment and at least during that period and for a couple of weeks after, her asthma wasn't as bad. Perhaps the mines have some other metals and the overall atmosphere is such that has a positive affect on the patients.

The salt lamps may not provide 'ions', but they are effective as moderate air fresheners nevertheless. There is a significant difference to the smell in the air when one is clearing out cooking odors, for example. So it does have some benefit, as well as looking pretty. (Also, if a lamp is on for more than an hour, a pool of liquid salt will form around the base of the lamp, so one should have some form of collection plate beneath the stand, and be sure to keep the electrical wiring that's hooked up to the light bulb inside the salt well clear of the pooling amounts.)

I LOVE scientific videos like this. Do salt lamps do anything? Of course not. Did Derek, a prestigious scientist, laugh it off and dismiss it just because it's yet another gimmick? No.

As someone who adores science, I cannot stand when scientists lift their nose at claims and hypothesizes, no matter how ridiculous, like salt lamps. The true scientific method tells us to test a hypothesis, no matter your preconceived ideas of the outcome. Did Derek know going into making this video that salt lamps are a gimmick? Yes. But did he still treat the claim with respect and test it before jumping to conclusions, as a true scientist should? YES.

Don't get me wrong, I understand the idea of ignoring conspiracy theories and fake science with the intent of not giving them any more unnecessary exposure, therefore spreading more scientific ignorance: the earth is flat, creation vs evolution, horoscopes, etc. But there is a line that true practicing scientists should stick to where they do not disrespect the scientific method just because the claim or hypothesis is hokey.

This video represents that idea perfectly. He came to the table with a claim, and did more research and testing than most scientists would ever consider, and that made his conclusion that salt lamps are, in fact, useless, based on fact and research. And guess what? He didn't disrespect anyone along the way, no matter his opinion on their claims.

Keep spreading the idea of responsible science.

I'm a little disappointed.
1) The mass spectrometer couldn't read the background ionization level expected in the lab, so we can't tell if it increased or not. Nor did it give any value translatable at ions/cm^3 to compare to the values he quoted earlier from various sources. (Yes, I know it would be hard to calibrate, but a zero from an insensitive detector doesn't mean much)
2) It didn't read positive ions to determine whether one type increased more than the other, even with the air ionizer.
3) He didn't explain how one could produce more negative than positive ions without pumping in electricity from another source. If the salt lamp did produce negative ions at first, wouldn't it build up a positive charge until it pulled them back very quickly?
Note that I am NOT hypothesizing that salt lamps might do anything to create negative ions, nor that they might be beneficial. I am highly skeptical of both claims. I just thought there were some holes in his debunking of the idea.

Thank you for explaining what you learned and applying some science- and measurement-based criticism to this odd hypothesis.

If water were to “liberate” chloride ions it would take an incredible amount of energy and leave behind positively charged sodium ions which would then break away from the larger mass over time. This would probably create positive ions in the air balancing it all out, and when the chloride and sodium once again met it would bond back together to form salt once more.

But of course that wouldn’t happen because the energy required to break the original bond is the equivalent of something like 800°C. It’s not going to happen in a lamp like this and it’s not going to release specifically negative ions.

I'm not going to claim ions magically accomplish anything science can't prove.
But I don't think the effects of "insignificant" ion concentrations should be entirely dismissed. Brief exposures to tiny (<ppm) concentrates of things like hormones and pheromones can profoundly affect biological functions, energy levels, mental processes, emotional states, etc. These puny influences aren't the actual mechanisms - they're just signals or triggers - but their effects on organisms still occur even though they lack sufficient mass or energy to cause such changes directly.
It seems strange to me that so many studies would inconclusively measure ion effects on humans - before a mountain of studies have already conclusively determined the effects of ions on other animals.

When the basic assumption behind these "health claims" is an argument from nature (We used to be exposed to more negatively charged air in nature, therefore it should be better for you). Then you can probably safely assume these claims have little to no scientific backing. "We used to experience more of this" is probably the most flawed form of logic. We used to live near more exposed sewage before urbanisation, but that doesn't mean living near exposed sewage is healthy even if it's more "natural". Humans used to be exposed to more sunlight, faeces, bacteria, decaying organic material, insects, parasites, toxins and more. But nobody (intellectual) is arguing that we expose ourselves to more of these things for health benefits. Natural doesn't mean good, artificial doesn't mean bad. Even knowing these things I'm still commonly affected by this logical fallacy so there's no shame in falling for it but we should strive to break this base assumption we often make.

Lamps like this can be DEADLY to your housecats. Cats love to sleep near warm things, and salt lamps do get warm.  But, because the lamp also is a large salt lump, your cat might lick enough of the salt to become seriously ill.  House cats are known to like salt more than is good for them, and there have been cases of cats who become gravely ill from licking salt lamps.  Too much salt can cause serious injury and even death for beloved housepets.  Tell your friends who have cats to be cautious and aware that cats can die from overeating the salt of these lamps.  Don't believe me?  I don't mind.  Google it.  Try "Salt lamps dangerous for cats".  That will give you lots of sites to chose from that can give you the straight info.  If you love your cats as much as I love mine, give those salt lamps a pass.  Thanks for reading!

Just for people who don’t know what an ion is, an ion is an atom that has a difference in number of protons and electrons. Metals have a positive ion since they lose their valency electrons to have an electronically stable configuration (less electrons than protons) while a lot of non metals have negative ions because they gain electrons to reach electronically stable configuration (more electrons than protons). Valency electrons are the outer most electrons on an atom btw.

I will be using this video in my Chemistry Classes and see if any of my students can come up with one GLARING omission in this video.  There’s something called The conservation of matter.  It was correctly pointed out that negative ions are produce by the gain of electrons, but those electrons have to come form somewhere.  They don’t just “POOF” into existence.  So whenever an electron is released and produces a negative ion there MUST be something that lost an electron and is now a positive ion.  So whenever a negative ion (anion) is generated, a positive ion (cation) is also generated and those are claimed to be bad for you.

The New York Times had a great article in February 2021,...showing that all the Himalayan salt lamps,....(the rock salt), is mined in Pakistan. It is that pink or rose colored salt. Most is sold for food prep, as a (spice) in culinary stores. The rest are manufactured into those salt lamps, and exported all over the world for resale. The salt does not come from mines in Himalaya. The most depressing part of the story,.....the miners in Pakistan, use pick axes, and dynamite,...the work is grueling and labor intensive,.....there are no safety standards, or protective clothing or use of work gloves, or face masks.  So the workers slave like dogs,.....and they breathe the salt dust, which is harmful to their lungs. They get paid mere pennies for their hard labor, too.

1:57 "process-ēz"? Why do people do this with the plural of "process" and "bias"; treating them like the plurals of analysis, diagnosis/prognosis, crisis, and so on? It's just a regular -es pluralization of a word. It comes across as an affectation as if to say, "This is the intelligent way to pronounce this plural". The plural gets that -ēz ending if the original singular form of the word ends in an -is like the examples above. Saying "processes" as "process-ēz" and "biases" as "baias-ēz" implies the singular forms of the words are "processis" and "biasis", respectfully.

The funny thing about this video is that you are clearly ignorant of Betteridge's Law Of Headlines (and Titles).
Intuitively, you understand it, but you don't know about it - and so you follow the headline's rules in your thumbnail.

What is “Fresh” air?

What always ticks me off about pseudoscience like this negative ions stuff is that it completely ignores some fundamental aspects of how nature works. You cannot just have isolated negative ions. If you could, that would be worth a dozen Nobel prizes.
For every negative ion you create, you also create positive charge somewhere. While you can separate electric charge by doing work, creating any meaningful charge density requires a bit more sophistication than simply heating up a block of salt.
In other words, even if the hot salt lamp were to give off negative ions, they'd leave behind a positively charged lamp which would attract all negative ions back to its surface. Even if you could prevent that from happening, as soon as you'd get close to the lamp or -- god forbid -- touched it, it would zap all negative charge it can away from you.

When it comes to the air ionizers and the supposed benefits of negative ions in the air, do ANY of the studies mention what happens to the positive charges/ions? Where do those end up? I feel like this point could have been explored a bit more in the video.

This is an aside remark... not so much on the salt lamp myth, (there could be some other electrimgnetic or para-psychological phenomenon), but on the concept of ozone being bad for health.  There is no scientific "proof" that ozone causes problems, unlike direct exposure to ultraviolet rays and cosmic rays.  Ozone we are  used to seeing generated in commutators of dc electric motors, (that smell of arcing), and in some welding processes. But Ozone (O3) is unstable and generates nascent oxygen. And nascent oxygen, a single atom of oxygen, is shortlived and converts to regular oxygen quickly.  In effect, two molecules of ozone would generate three molecules of oxygen.  So what's  wrong with that, if we get more pure oxygen around us.  Yes, breathing ozone directly could be harmful... they use Ozone as a "bleaching" agent in several products where ammonia or chlorine bleach could hazardous.  But if the electronic ionizer generates some ozone, and if we keep it at a safe distance, what's wrong with a but of extra purified oxygen in the air.

there are some important details left out here.. around the world there are wind conditions that are known by name and carry a particular ionic charge, along with carrying a decades- or even centuries-old reputation for their side effects, and which all correspond to the (still not quite proven) supposed effects of negative and positive ions. for example, in southern california the santa ana winds are negatively charged, and while some people dislike the dry eyes they cause, they are widely known from direct experiences to have a mood-uplifting effect. in contrast, in european alpine areas a wind known as der föhn is positively charged and is known to cause headaches, bad moods, and even compulsive swearing. weighed in total, maybe it's not conclusive evidence but very compelling nonetheless. the video's conclusion didn't sit right with me.. saying that the ionic concentration per cm3 is too low to have appreciable effect just based on numbers leaves out the possibility that the human body might have biological receptors capable of detecting them, perhaps as an evolved trait that made humans seek fresh air for improved survival and fitness

Hello Veritasium.
If you browse thru electronic hobby magazines from the '60, you will find a staple project of the period. The name: "Negative Ion generator".
There is an Americium capsule (poached from smoke detectors), affixed to a fine metal grid. The metal grid is connected to a -3,000 V power supply (made by a bunch of diodes and capacitors connected as a series of voltage doubler from main AC).
A fan blows air thru the metal grid. The power supply attracts the positive ions generated by the Americium, and the fan blows out the negative ions.
Electricity alone can't produce the good negative ions, but only ozone, as you also experienced.

I’ve been a psychiatrist for 30+ years and have seen many products; pharmaceuticals as well as nutraceuticals, essential oils, and homeopathic remedies advertised to help depression and relieve anxiety. A rule of thumb is 1/3 of people will have a positive response to anything (a placebo response). New therapies being brought to market  try to reduce the placebo response among subjects by eliminating those who respond to a placebo during a “washout” phase of the test.  With all of that said, if someone comes to me and wants to use their product—unless it is actually dangerous—I will tell them to give it a try because even a placebo response is a response. My father, a rural MD in the 1950-60s, made house calls with a small supply of medications to be used by the patient until a prescription could be filled. He had brown aspirin and white aspirin for sprains/strains; the only difference being the color. Many people would ask for the brown aspirin when given the choice if they were told that they were stronger.

Ozone (O3) is extremely rare in nature; its primary source in modern times is when it is created in a reaction between pollutants. Therefore any study that claims that Ozone is bad for you also has to control for the effects of the pollutants. Ozone, or trioxygen, is an inorganic molecule with the chemical formula O ₃. It is a pale blue gas with a distinctively pungent smell. It is an allotrope of oxygen that is much less stable than the diatomic allotrope O ₂, breaking down in the lower atmosphere to O ₂. Depending on where it is in the atmosphere, ozone affects life on Earth in either good or bad ways.

Be careful. There have been some products from China marketed to produce negative ions that actually contained thorium oxide powder, a radioactive by product of processing uranium for reactors. There were in the form of plastic bracelets and pendants made of plastic or silicone rubber containing the thorium oxide powder. And there were stainless steel tubes shaped like a ballpoint pen that contained thorium oxide powder. They were radioactive, not enough to harm with casual exposure but similar to uranium minerals the amount of radiation was such that you could be harmed by long term contact with your body or by ingesting or breathing the particles. Silicone is soft so a bracelet worn daily shed tiny particles containing thorium that could get in your body. The thorium has been removed from some of the products that once contained it and hopefully no one is putting it in products any more. If you have any of these negative ion

We use a type of negative ion generators - electrostatic precipitators as part of scrubbers to clean power plant exhaust. Literally millions of dollars per power plant to install an electrostatic precipitator.

NASA developed negative ion generators to reduce dust and PM 2.5 inside space craft.

For less than $100 on Amazon you can get negative ion generators and negative ion counters.

They are used to clean the air. Seriously. They are cheap and knock down dust. They noticably remove odors from air, remove smoke and dust, by knocking then down with electric charge. You mostly vaccum up all the particles.

So if you have asthma, poor air quality - they do have newer tech than the 90's sharper image electrostatic precipitator that do not generate ozone, and do improve air quality.

Or at least work well enough that we actually put them on coal burning power plants the meet EPA requirements.

So no idea if the make you happy. But they are used by engineers to clean the air.

On a cellular level, ions are bad for us. In fact, this is considered to be "oxidation" and one of the main constituents of oxidation in the cells is H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide). Antioxidants are what move around through the cell and neutralize oxidized molecules before they do too much damage. In this case, "oxodized" simply refers to an atom or molecule that has been ionized. An ionized atom or molecule can cause damage to other molecules, be stealing atoms or displacing them.
As for breathing them into your lungs, I can't see how they would be beneficial, since they would also cause damage to the very sensitive cells that absorb and exchange gases. But, as you say near the end of this video, the ratio of ionized atoms/molecules to unionized is extremely low, so the impact is negligible. Unless, of course, you're sucking down ozone, which is bad for you.

TL;DR of below:there simply is no way to completely cut out uncontrolled environmental variables for studies about stuff like mood,so it is really damn hard to prove the effect. t oget even close to 'conclusive evidence' would be if 2000 trustworthy studies by 2000 different people/teams from all across the world,with large sample sizes, decently controlled yet vastly different setups, ALL say the same thing.


as for the studies...i studied psychology for a bit, and it's really obvious that anything based on moods/personality/behaviour/... is really hard to prove, cause there are no real 100% controlled environments. putting people in a situation like the added ions and then asking them their happiness level is subjective as balls, maybe they had a good day, maybe the ate something they really liked,maybe they saw a pretty butterfly just outside, maybe they actually had a bad day,... there is no controlling these environmental factors.
how about putting them in a controlled environment you say? sure, but no. social interaction is quite volatile, a good conversation can boost moods, and a bad one can destroy them, even just finding one of your co-subjects pretty can boost your mood...so you'd need a setting with as little social contact as possible, ok we can do that. but then theres the next issue, no 2 people are the same. some won't mind being alone for a while and have minimal effects from the isolation, others hate being alone, and having them read a book/play a game/whatevs is also not doable, cause depending on the chapter in the book/whether they win/lose...you guessed it, influence.
I for one like social contact, but don't mind being alone that much, but if i'd jsut have to sit somewhere doing nothing at all, i'd get frustrated out of boredom really easily. others might use it to meditate. ok, lets use the same person 2 times, and put them in the same situation 2 times except we only change the ions? well that's allready getting closer, but it's still not 100%, why, you ask? if you'd hated the setup cause you had to do nothing in a room for a whole day, then the knowledge of the first run could influence the second run, or vice versa, halfway through you can remember you'd have to do this twice and be really bummed out, but then be happier the second time cause it's over now. or the other way around. and even then let's say you see it as a day of meditating, which you do monthly, ok sure, so you don't mind doing it twice, no prob that's good, less direct effects, but....last month could've been a better month for you than this month.
so, long story short, there simply is no way to completely cut out uncontrolled environmental variables for studies like this.
combine that with the fact that long term studies are a lot more reliable than jsut taking a quick snapshot....

Before I ask a question I want to remark that I find your videos refreshingly clear and informative! Now my question. What about the incredibly strong coulomb forces between charged particles? Wouldn't any negatively charged particle be associated with a positively charged particle nearby that would rapidly recombine with it?  I would think that the concentration of negative ions you quoted would be associated with an equal concentration of positively charged ions. Any concentration of charged particles would be the result of a steady state determined by the ambient production rate of ion pairs in competition with their very rapid recombination due to their extremely strong coulomb attraction. In the ionosphere, with densities low enough for satellites to orbit with little drag, the concentrations can be much higher than the atmospheric numbers you quoted, because oppositely charged particles are orbiting one another at distances too large to neutralize one another frequently. A volume of ionospheric space is essentially charge neutral. At atmospheric densities three body collisions are frequent, making it easy to allow oppositely charged particles to migrate to one another and either bond or exchange an electron, thereby removing themselves from the ion count.

Good video, but "Biological plausibility" is a highly questionable property to use for evaluating research. If you use that a criterion, when there IS ever a novel biological mechanism, the bias of previous research against its plausibility will automatically preclude the discovery. Quantum biology is one example, the other is organic chemistry, which researchers thought was "implausible, because how could living matter have a similar chemical make-up to non-living matter????" The thought was preposterous at the time. Hence biological plausibility is very contested as a measure for veracity of research results.

Derek, please debunk the widespread assumption that infrared radiation can directly heat bulk ocean water:
https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/2017JC013351
The predominant light that penetrates earth's oceans is visible sunlight. Thus, sunlight itself heats oceans. Fewer clouds (particularly cirrus) should result in ocean heating.
Why are stratospheric cirrus clouds dissolving? Liquid and solid water particles are excellent infrared absorbers, which causes them to evaporate.
Therefore, more stratospheric CO2 should result in fewer cirrus clouds. Note that cirrus clouds themselves are an important component of Earth's greenhouse effect.

Recent Discovery: Water micro droplets naturally possess a negatively charged (alkaline) surface. The effect is reduced for larger droplets, which have a smaller surface to volume ratio. The droplets are therefore likely overall neutral with a positive (acidic) interior.
https://news.stanford.edu/2019/08/26/water-droplets-spontaneously-produce-hydrogen-peroxide/
This explains why fog droplets do not collide (like charges repel). It takes less than one excess charge per million atoms to provide enough electric field for mictodrop repulsion.
Even normal-sized raindrops should be very collision resistant. This renders implausible the existing theory of thunderstorm charge generation.

Nice one.   I've long been aware of the negative effects of ozone.   And when high voltage ion generators started becoming popular, it was clear they produced as much ozone as anything else, as I could clearly smell it.   Yet many people have been taken in by these generators, not realizing the harmful effects of ozone and falling for the marketing of these devices.   Even if negative ions are good things, a high voltage generator is not the way to get them.   At least, the latest ones using Himalayan Salt are a bit more harmless, though as we see here they may not actually generate the ions they're claimed to. I have known little to nothing about negative ions before this video.  I appreciate the information.  It was very interesting.  However, some of these experiments seem a bit off to me.  They just don’t seem to go far enough, only extrapolating surface information.  For example, if you wiped water on the salt of the lamp (not the electrical components obviously, just the salt) ever so often to keep it damp, would it then create negative ions?  What about rain?  Is there an inordinate amount of negative ions in something like a rain storm that has no lightning or even in a light rain shower?  How about a shower in a bathroom?  What about fog?  If so in fog, does a fog machine that once was used, say back in the day in dance clubs, create negative ions?  Shouldn’t experiments be done, then, on people regarding being in these situations, not letting them know what the experiment is about but that it’s just not harmful, in order to get better info on whether negative ions are actually beneficial?  This video on this subject matter just reminds me of an artist’s common mistake:  Often an artist thinks s/he needs not to overwork a piece and stops before any of the detail work would actually make it a masterpiece.  Just my take is all.  But this is my normal complaint about science today:  Science is often used to “debunk” crack theories yet comes across just as crack because the real science is skewed in order to get across a political or personal view.  I know I’m not the only one, which is why so many people are outright rebelling against science now as it seems to have become the religion of the elites in power to further oppress the masses.  Just sayin’.  So I conclude with saying that, if you want to get to the general populace who do in reality have minds of their own, you might want to do more work to better illuminate your findings; otherwise, you may just be alienating more people from ever wanting to have anything to do with science and thus people like you.

When I was in college, I attached a wire from an ionizer to my ankle while I slept. The goal was to ionize the air in my lungs, and kill germs on my skin. As long as I didn't touch anything else conductive while the wire was attached, I wouldn't get shocked. My finding was that this caused me to start coughing a lot.
I decided to stop doing that, and so I attached the wire to a sheet of aluminum foil that I taped to my door. This kept my roommates from barging in on me (because the doorknob would shock them) and it gave them an entertaining method of delivering my mail, which was to fling it at my door and let it stick to the statically charged wood.
For whatever reason, I decided to use the electric arc from the door-capacitor to zap a small mole on my arm to see if it would make the mole go away. It did make the mole go away, but it was replaced by a scar.

I then moved on to attach the wire to a piece of aluminum window screen that was over the surface of a 20"x20" furnace filter that was taped to the intake of a similarly sized box fan. The static charge caused a very fine powder (presumably from tiny particles in the air) to build up on the filter. I assume the charge enhanced the effectiveness of the filter, but periodically, there were discharges from the screen to the metal frame of the box fan. When my computer (approximately 15 feet and one internal wall away from the unit) started randomly locking up, I went to a command prompt to see what was going on. I saw random characters showing up, as if they were being typed. I thought I had been hacked, but I noticed the faint sound of a 'snap' every time the characters appeared. Evidently, the discharge was causing interference in my computer.


There's my experience with electrical ionizers. If you were curious about these things, I don't suggest repeating the experiments involving electrifying yourself or zapping moles. Electrifying your doorknob is always a good idea though. It keeps out people who are too daft to touch the knob with a metal object first to discharge it, and/or are too wimpy to discharge it with an area of skin that is not a finger.

Okay, two research method notes:

(1) Could anions have some catalytic &/or bio-cascade impact disproportionate to their tiny concentrations? Maybe. My industry (specialty chemicals) is super aware of the toxins that harm folks at ppm or even sometimes ppb levels. That's always baffled intuition, for me. How can 50 mg Vanadium per cubic meter of air be harmful? Or 2 ppm of H2S? But bio data proves it is. Clearly, tiny amounts of Some things can have big effects. Granted, that statement falls way short of a mechanistic hypothesis for anion benefits. But it does counter your video's claim that rarefied concentrations alone might justify discounting any possible impact.

(2) The frustrating sparsity of dosing controls in the majority of experiments actually strengthens the possibility that the anions might be beneficial. (Not your implication of the other way 'round.) Any individual study that is correctly run in every other respect, but which under-dosed subjects, should find little-or-no benefit. So only those studies that gave consistent, sufficient doses actually allow us to assess the hypothesis of anions benefits. At 6:47 and 7:11, you cite studies reporting benefits at high concentrations of anions. Were those perhaps from a small subset of studies that used consistent high levels of anions? I am Not saying I necessarily believe so; only that the correct path to an answer follows the above logic.

Regardless, great video. The use of the GC-mass spec really proves the salt lamps are just pretty placebos (fine as long as that's all you're expecting). And the ozone measurement nipped in the bud any nascent musing I had of ordering up a ionizer from Amazon. But I am still wondering if there might be a synthetic path to making cheap tourmaline. (A too-quick Google found a Russian website that could easily be a scam, and it doesn't claim it's cheap.) Perhaps there exists some composition (in a possibly extended family of tourmaline-like compounds) that optimizes ion formation, without necessarily making clear crystals for jewelry, which might therefore be easier/cheaper to synthesize.

Speaking of ions, you generate ions by burning glucose. Buring glucose results in Co2, which can react with the water inside your blood, which makes H2Co3, which is a weak acid, but still can disperse a Hydrogen ion and thus transform to HCo3-. Ions absorbed by your body will only influence your blood pH level; A change in it by even 0.01 will knock you out. Fear not; your blood has a buffer which takes the radicals (ions) and neutralises them (such as antiradicals).

Big fan of veritasium, keep doing your thing! However, I fear this particular video may be flawed. Many brands of air purifiers release ozone into a room intentionally to kill airborne mold or bacteria. You generally aren't supposed to be in the room while this is happening. I never read that the ozone was a consequence of ion formation and you can certainly buy purifiers that claim to be ozone free. Also as I understand it the health effects of negatively ionized air is not because of serotonin production but rather the same as that of antioxidants found in food. Molecules with high electronegativity such as oxygen steal electrons from places in your body destroying covalent bonds and thus compromising your cells. The negative ions are to provide these extra electrons and satisfy the electron hungry free radicals. Though as you pointed out the evidence is conflicted as to the real world efficacy of ion producing devices but I would argue it is far too early to rule out their benefits entirely.

I don't think you did a good job of conveying that referring to 'ions' as though they're 'some sort of thing' is asinine for the same reason referring to 'chemicals' as though they're 'some sort of thing' is asinine.

Ions have no specific properties, it's a category distinction. Knowing that something is an 'ion' tells you absolutely nothing meaningful about that thing, in the same way that knowing something is a 'chemical' tells you absolutely nothing meaningful about that thing.

I'll leave 'meaningful' undefined for the sake of helping people think about what it means to be meaningful. Though if I get enough of one particularly silly reply I'll clarify.

In living organisms, biologically active could be substances in such minute quantities that modern technology if able to detect may not be  certain how biologically active is the amount in question. In other words, even if we are talking about extremely small amounts, we do not know how significant they are in their action. Some poisons can be very potent in very small amounts (LSD), when we talk about particles even more so. Radiation for example….

I am blown away by the staging of this video. In this video, I first start out a sceptic. That "ions benefits are a hoax". Then you allure me to believe there actually is something behind it with the number of papers, the proven results, the research and etc. You make me buy the idea so that when you reveal the truths, I doubt I will ever forget the reasons for why it is unscientific.

In the process, you also cement how "dangerous" it can be to only read an abstract and even worse: be read an abstract from a news source with an agenda. A study may seem scientific on the surface, while in truth it may have many flaws and fallacies that invalidates it.

Well, at least you've re-motivated me to do a proper paper/video at some point on the effects of ionization and ozonification on biological systems. It's amazing how even your lab guys were illiterate on how ozone and smog inter-relate, and how what is an indicator of bad air in one case is actually what makes good air in another.

Actual in-situ case studies with air ionizers in farms has been shown to reduce piglet mortality significantly, and ozone sanitation of food-borne pathogens reduces health risks from residual microbes by an order of magnitude. Radio-ionizers have such a dramatic visible effect in enclosed smoky spaces that you would drop all doubt when you saw it.

The point is, you need to know what the chemistry is doing at the time it is doing it, and what the measurements mean under the circumstances. You need to know what is a cause and what is an effect, and it's amazing how bad how many people with degrees are at exactly that kind of thing. I continue to be amazed at the ability of academic specialists to be horrendously ignorant of anything outside their super-narrow field of inquiry, to the point that they actually propagate dangerous myths.

Ironically, if you put a radio-ionizer/ozonator combo unit in an enclosed home, building or barn, the animals in the place know exactly what to do. They cuddle up next to the damn thing as close as they can and breathe clean air that isn't full of carcinogenic aerosolized ethyl-plastics. It smells like a sunny day at the shore, and they know that means good.

The meta data supports a strong association between exposure to  high and low concentrations of negative ions and a reduction of both acute and chronic depression. Derek's contention that the effects must be from lowering pollutants near the test subjects is conjecture,  and not backed by science. The video suffers from confirmation bias, as he admits to thinking it was nonsense from the beginning and offers conclusions of studies that are neutral or negative, and support his opinion. He admits to only looking at a fraction of the studies available and selects only those with imperfect methodology to take issue with. The video  also suffers from straw men arguments by wasting time talking about ridiculous salt lamps that are obvious frauds with absurd claims. "Of course, negative ions are what you breathe in and produces serotonin in the body and serotonin is like the primary neurotransmitter in your whole body and all living things and that's what makes you feel good."

Wow.

Ever have that pleasant rush of a click of a mouse or touch of the screen to like a post? That's not serotonin. That's acetylcholine at the nicotinic receptor of the neuromuscular junction. You don't do anything without it. Seriously, you don't move a muscle without acetylcholine.

Ever not do something stupid? Thank gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) for that. It is a very important inhibitory neurotransmitter. It helps to keep balance within your brain. Balance is important, right?

Want to increase your serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine neurotransmitters all at once? All of the "good" neurotransmitters at the same time. Excellent, right? Just go and smoke some crack. Yes, cocaine increases all of these "good" neurotransmitters, that's a biochemical fact. OK, so your heart might proverbially explode, or more realistically die a painful death of life-threatening dysrhythmia and ischemia/ infarction due to coronary vasospasm. No, I do not recommend using cocaine, unless you have a nosebleed. It is a very good combined vasoconstrictor/ anesthetic, every once in a while, for that particular purpose, when administered by a trained and licensed professional, and in the appropriate clinical circumstances. Aside from that, it is a pretty terrible and toxic drug.

I've seen the "negative is actually positive (good) for u" statement before... It's part of that whole idea that things are the opposite of what u think, like flipped images, color inversion, stuff like that.... But free radicals are positive h+ Ions, as well as acidic stuff, and heavy metals also, and I've read that negative Ions help detoxify by attaching to those things and being excreted out of the body. Alkaline or basic solutions are also more negative, or less concentration of positive Ions.

So I would believe that negative Ions have a good effect on health... I think they are called anions as well? I wonder if there is a good, safe source for them. I've heard of orgone but not much clear data on it, plus not sure if it's generating the good or bad type of Ions.

Also, I wouldn't be too quick to dismiss low concentration of certain Ions or particles having an effect.... Very often a low% of something like in solutions or crystals, even 1%, is enough to dramatically change the crystal matrix to form a different structure or color change. Some very unique metal alloys get properties like rust proof from just small bits of sulfur, phosphorus, or other minor elements being mixed in... It's all proportions and the right structure to get certain effects.

~13:50 - Your reasoning is kinda flawed. Personally, I think the whole "negative ions" thing is junk, but... In silicon semiconductors, the there are about 5*10^22 atoms/cm^3. In a typical doped n-type material, there might only be 10^13 dopant atoms. That's less than 1ppm of dopant or 1 dopant atom for every 10^9 silicon atoms.

With your logic, the dopants shouldn't really have any affect on the surrounding silicon, because the concentration is SO low... but the entire modern world around us is absolutely made possible because of this ridiculous effect that 1 in a million atoms has.

Is it that absurd to wonder the same thing for "negative ions"? Personally, I think it's all nonsense, but the logic you used is kinda faulty. Great video, though!

During the recent fires in CA I did a little research on air purifiers and I found that California no longer allows Air Purifiers to be sold in the state which produce any significant amounts of Ozone. Many of the Air Purifiers on Amazon were of the correct type, but flagged by Amazon as not being sellable to CA addresses. I expect, though, that they cleared the air pretty quickly due to demand because a week later they were available. In the mean time, though, I hopped down to the local Home Depot and snagged one of the last Air Purifiers they had... fully rated to not produce Ozone. That is, it only had a carbon element, a HEPA filter, and a fan, and that's it. No electro ionic gizmo cleaning elements.

I'm very happy with my air purifier... honestly, if CA hadn't banned the ozone producing ones I would never have known that were actually bad for my health. Nice to see some validation.

I would say that "easy to remember" is actually not the main factor in password vulnerability, length is. It's EXTREMELY easy to figure out a 4 digit number like a PIN if the system is being compromised. Where "easy to remember" became a problem was in the era of 8 character passwords where people would use Rainbow Tables (basically shoving a dictionary with common letter/number swaps through your password). This approach falls apart as the password gets longer. After about 16 characters, you basically just need to make sure you're not using meaningful phrases. "May the force be with you!" is long, but it's also common and easy to guess. Picking random words like "dinosaur corporate banana distance" (or XKCD's "correct horse battery staple") is weird, easy enough to remember, and too long for a dictionary attack like Rainbow Tables and way too long for a brute force attack.

Now, that said, the next problem is why LastPass is relevant and helpful - having the best password ever is totally worthless if you use it on five sites and someone hacks one of those sites and gets the password database. LastPass helps you keep track of all your passwords so you aren't tempted to reuse a password and risk losing multiple accounts at once. (I use one of their competitors for Android, but LastPass is more highly recommended in general.)

My problem with the negative ion craze is that, with the exception of radioactivity, all of the sources of negative ions produce positive ions. Therefore, "high concentration of negative ions" also means "high concentration of positive ions". Maybe total ion concentration plays some (possibly indirect) biological role, but we shouldn't single out the negative ions, since positive ones always come with them. Otherwise, we would have highly charged pockets of air, and you would feel the static electricity or shocks far more frequently.

I have to say, I am actually rather troubled and disappointed by this video -- and this as someone who has been watching you for literally years and has always been a huge fan. For the first 1/2 - 2/3rds of the video, you seem to be implying that there is a scientific basis for negative ions having a real effect on a person. You cite results from multiple papers to make it seem credible without discussing any of the flaws of the papers, to the point that I was even beginning to think you genuinely believed there was a real effect (I nearly closed the video and went to go look up some papers myself, because I genuinely could not believe this was a real thing -- and luckily you saved me quite a lot of time by raising/discussing many of the issues I was contemplating) -- it's only much later in the video that you quite suddenly shift in tone and discuss the flaws in the papers and essentially show that this is all bunk. But for many viewers, the subtleties and importance of methodologies,  blinding participants and researchers, sample sizes and statistical significance may be lost on them. Not to mention, they may not watch the entire video, and I have no doubt that people with an agenda will clip out portions of this video to suit their needs and piggyback on your name and reputation as someone of good standing among the science-literate to further said agenda. Quite frankly, if I saw only the first 1/2 - 2/3rds of this video, I would've been extremely shocked and surprised, not to mention extremely confused -- and I consider myself quite scientifically literate and a healthy skeptic. For many other viewers, I can't help but think that they will ignore the latter part of the video and the first half will only reinforce previously held beliefs/positions that there genuinely is a real effect -- not to mention it's likely to confuse many others. And it's not that I mind that you investigated something most would dismiss out of hand as pseudoscience to begin with -- quite to the contrary, I think it's good to do these sorts of videos, to show that a responsible scientist can and should impartially investigate ideas they may already have had a negative or positive bias toward. The problem I have is the way you discussed and presented the material -- maybe I'm overreacting, but I genuinely think you did the larger scientific community (which is constantly having to fight a never ending war against ignorance, pseudoscience and the like) a serious disservice by not being much more up front about the obvious flaws in the papers/research you looked at and discussing those from the beginning. If you want to point out that there were some interesting results that warranted more research, by all means -- but you should have been much more adamant in putting to rest any notion that negative ions have any real effect, in my opinion. Anyway, just my two cents.

Oh I really was hoping you would take the last part further regarding the interaction of ions and pollutants.

I work as a HVAC designer and the industry is really trying hard to convince us we can drastically cut ventilation by using ions. The premises being that the typically un-measured pollutants like VOCs can be broken down and controlled via ions. Also, filtration can be of a lower efficiency since the ions will cause ultra fine particals to clump and/or settle by gravity. Then we can just use CO2 levels to meter the ventilation rate to the building.

They of course come with all their papers supporting their statements. But like this, its hard to believe even published research sometimes as there are errors in methods. But since I'm not a research scientist, it's harder for me to catch them.

Anyways, great video and thanks.

My mom got me one of these Himalayan rock salt lamps. She's very much into that sort of thing but looking at it I start thinking about "okay where are the negative ions supposedly coming from?" One hypothesis is that it's acting as a sort of Optical capacitor. University of Michigan has done some research into this field where wavelengths of Light May induce semi conductive material that is translucent in order to deposit charge on surfaces. Could this be happening naturally within the structure of salt? No idea but I'm pretty sure the tiny wattage white likely does not produce much of any ions. Unlikely any natural light would be a greater candidate if that hypothesis was true. Does the EMF likely matters to the geometry of any set structure such as a rock salt lamp.
Negative ions do seem like they would have at least an interaction with the human body as charged is likely necessary that we may take for granted in most chemical reactions. In that we just assumed that there is enough charge density in any given location for electrons to be shared in chemical compositions. So along those lines negative ions May assist with a natural chemistry at the body and thus leading to different positive effects. However it may not be true if different amount of charge may have ill effects or undesired consequences. I think it's a field that needs more exploration and to bring it home into mainstream science.
